conclusion: Let the mass of each wooden block be m.
All four blocks move together with the same acceleration a, so F = (4m) a ⇒ a = F / (4m).
Blocks B and C are connected by a spring, and the spring must supply the force needed for blocks A + B and C + D to share the same acceleration.
By Newton’s third law, the spring force on C equals the spring force on B in opposite directions.
Considering blocks A and B as one subsystem (mass 2m): F – F_spring = (2m) a ⇒ F_spring = F − 2m a ⇒ F_spring = F − 2m (F/4m) = F − F/2 = F/2.
The spring pulls block C toward the right with magnitude F/2.
For blocks C and D together (mass 2m), the spring force F/2 to the right must give them the required acceleration: F/2 = (2m) a = 2m (F/4m) = F/2.
This is consistent, confirming equilibrium of accelerations.
For block D alone, the static friction from block C must satisfy f_s = m a = m (F/4m) = F/4.
The static friction force acting on block D has magnitude f_s = F⁄4.
